Hvvt_TXqD_GiOiI19ivYqg.text: We have had really great night there together with my friends. we all enjoyed the place and the experience was amazing!

Vg3C9PwLS1ABYN3rBAs28Q.text: We had a great night out there! Eventhough it was karaoke and im definitely no fan of it The drinks are good, but costy Staff was friendly and ahe atmosphere was great, the people enjoyed themselves singing along to songs from 80s 90s and recent songs. Cool night!

wfJWkOqLDWfe_tx7kl2K8w.text: Bigger, cleaner and better than the Soho Lucky Voice, I had a fantastic night out here with all my friends. I don't know if there are more songs on the playlist, but it felt like it. This is my new favourite karaoke place in London.

Hs_eqxhU8Y2ktIW0geVbtA.text: I went here for a friends birthday, I'm not really the best singer but you don't have to be. It was a lot of fun and you can choose from any of your favorite songs you wont to sing.

BOSbIc9PcjC01nJUZTnxyg.text: What can I say, its a great night out! Slick, funky interiors, good service and great music and thats just the front end. The obvious attraction is the private karaoke booths that are perfect for a quick sing-along or your own private party. Brilliant selection of tracks, really has something for everyone. The room also comes with a collection of props such as inflatable guitars and shiny hats to make the experience that much more fun, its a gauranteed laugh

TQYAJLjadY_ZL0P2TwvFrQ.text: A better venue to their Poland Street location, much bigger bar and a better layout. The drinks were flying down our necks and so didn't need a mic or indeed a private room! Great fun, gets everyone and so I highly recommended to anyone looking to hire a venue for a party or just a room with a few of your mates.

UwoBrTXkYUmApRRNMs4wWw.text: Never been to Lucky Voice before the Qype party and was really blown away! Not only was the venue fantastic but the staff were REALLY friendly and welcoming and the drinks were fantastically well priced! What I loved the most about Lucky Voice are the private karaoke rooms!. Being someone who doesn't exactly like getting up on stage in front of 100 strangers to sing Karaoke, the private rooms are just brilliant, and at no stage did we feel pressured to pay for extra time or hurried out the room when our time was up, plus the karaoke props were fantastic! I can not recommend this place enough - and can't wait to go back again with some mates for another awesome night out!

1AL_KoQJvaCXmLzGOi7DUg.text: the crowd is awesome and the events  worth going too!

kyHdHQAIwPmVKprRBaLcJQ.text: No doubt you want your first time to be somewhere special - Lucky voice is definitely the place! I couldn't have asked for a better venue to lose my karaoke cherrystaff were friendly and welcoming, drinks were well priced considering the area and the cocktails are potent enough to put the malotov variety to shame. The private karoake booths seemed a bit of a wierd concept - but after the 80's pub quiz (we definitely could have benefited from having some, ahem, older people on our team), not to mention a few of the afore-said cocktails, the genius of the idea dawned on me. Although there were a few strangers in the room, I had indulged in enough liquid courage to hijack the mic. There's also no using that old excuse of Oh they don't have any songs I like so I'm gonna sit this round out Nahuh. Think of a song you would do Karaoke. They have it. They also have the two cover versions and the one-hit wonder from the lead singers solo project. If you can find a song you wanna sing that they don't have, I will buy you a beer myself. Would definitely reccommend Lucky Voice for a good night and a laugh with some mates. I will be back, once my voice has recovered

RDWijLgkM7hhsrFxrhKxTA.text: I pass LuckyVoice every day but have I ever had the chance to sing? Not until last night! I'm not the most confident singer in the world so I spent some quality time in the rather gorgeous main bar drinking their amazingly yummy cocktails. Fruity and long, I managed 3 before I was finally dragged off into one of the rooms. These aren't any old karaoke rooms. They're dark and sultry with long leather(ish) sofa's. Above you is a patterned ceiling which I at first hoped was a depiction of pac man but turned out to be hearts and crosses. The singing itself was a blast. With golden oldies such as Grease and current hits like Gaga's Bad Romance, the sound quality was a lot better than the singing. The best bit? The dress up box brought to the room by our ever-smiling waitress. Inside were two wigs (one pink!), a toy microphone and two BLOW UP GUITARS! Clearly a step up from air guitar. Would I go again? Definitely, particularly since I discovered this morning they also run Cocktail Masterclasses. Any excuse for a party.

UZ4kxS2EErWusjvSsAME3A.text: Though my singing skills are terrible my half Japanese part can't be more than happy when hears the word k-a-r-a-o-k-e. So I was thrilled when I had the opportunity to sing along at Lucky Voice last night in one of the Qype events. I had been there before, but only this time I could have the whole karaoke experience and was as a karaoke should be: really fun. I was really surprise with the range of songs, that goes from classic 80's to current TV shows' tunes (they have a Glee set). In our booth you could hear from Total Eclipse of Heart to Flight of the Conchords' Most Beautiful Girl in the Room, all intensely sung. Even if you're not keen about karaoke I'm pretty sure their amazing cocktails (they all seem very sweet from the menu, but once you try they're just perfect) and shots will worth the effort to hear you're friends loosing their voices all night long. Said that Lucky Voice is guaranteed fun.

proEfmc4LX6DVN0f-85QoQ.text: There is something special about going into one of their karaoke booths and unleashing the inner demon of rock legends! Friendly staff, great selection of drinks. Software for managing songs could be a little better, great songlist available and the wigs + blow up guitars were a nice touch. This venue is brilliant for group nights out. Am begging my company to arrange the next event at this place!

4Kg5zd6PvOOsc5j1OlUX-g.text: OMG! Awesom-est place ever! The party never ends here and staff is very cool.

CnVsb_DKFgnRaGybmMbhzQ.text: Brilliant, expensive fun. This is in the unit where Bierodrome used to be, so has a really nice big bar as a consequence. As for the karaoke, it's passable. They booths are reasonably well designed, the only downside being the software all being from the mid 90s. Go on the company dime, or you'll have arguments over the bill at the end.

LiZKsEgS37LQFahOrh36Ww.text: Very comfortable place. I am not really a good singer but with the help of 1-2 drinks I think it was OK. If you have a good company then Lucky Voice will be nice for you. The prices are regular to cheap in my opinion.

u6vuPV4jfxOI99-nDd-tmg.text: It is a cosy place with a great atmosphere! I am not much of singer at all but I love having a drink or two there while my friends pretend to be rock stars. Service is great, pricing is reasonable  I really enjoy being there! 5 stars from me

rhDxtxkDYJheauZPtQR_nw.text: Lucky Voice is a real treat for those of us who can't wait to show of our vocal 'talents', but only after a stiff drink or three. Happily it allows you to indulge in drinking and singing, with some seriously drinkable cocktails and some of the most well kitted-out karaoke booths I've visited. Compared to the Soho branch, Lucky Voice Islington is far more roomy, making it quite possible to spend and evening drinking with friends in the bar, without necessarily singing. I have to admit, I've never managed this without caving in and booking a singing slot, mind you...

5OV0opP6E-fBasEpZG3Kiw.text: Fantastic bar, fantastic staff, fantastic range of songs to humiliate yourself with... what more could you want in a karaoke bar? I know where this microphone diva is having her next birthday party...

8gE0cu97WWA8ZWrramLevA.text: Mad wigs, mental cocktails, beach ball sized afros, 80's music, and the one and only Flava Flav - you could've been forgiven for thinking you'd arrived at one of Snoop's dinner parties. Alas Snoop was a no show, but the Qype party at Lucky Voice was still the shizzle. The staff here are fantastic hosts; keeping the karaoke fuel flowing whilst you shout out The Final Countdown da da da at the top of your voice. To top things off you don't even need to air guitar, as Lucky Voice provide some awesome inflatable props. Highly recommended, even if, like me, your singing sounds like a mentally ill cat stuck in a washing machine.

dhjUt9jCH0ffvuYKoQ1CUg.text: Yet another review from a happy hungover birthday party attendee! Yes, we had plenty of fun last night in the big pink temple of caterwauling. More than plenty. Even though our popularity could have outdone us, nobody seemed all too upset at not having a table to huddle around and look serious while answering the quiz questions. Mainly, everyone was too busy dancing and singing along to the snippets of songs, getting a little bit upset as each one finished but restarting with renewed vigour every time the next snippet started. The atmosphere was great and it is due in part to the staff here, who aren't just good at their jobs, they actually seem that they are hugely enjoying themselves. That's enough to get any party started. The drinks are great - Asahi on tap (but only in half pints), decent cocktails for £7, a great lot of spirits that I can't remember being too expensive. er. Having not actually done any karaoke, Lucky Voice will have to rest on its four-starred laurels until I return to do some to see if it is deserved

PXHXKWYZG5rxpuduUE9uSw.text: I came here last night for the Qype 2nd Birthday and had a whale of a time! Really lovely staff, reasonably priced drinks, large tables to fit all your friends round and the private karaoke rooms with songs and props for you and your mates to rock out in faux privacy (non sound proof booths = uh oh!). For helping facilitate yet another great Qype party they get five stars! Yeah, you heard, five stars!

s2k7inwReOCV7LmbPCNQ3A.text: My voice is crap, as such I'm terrified of karaoking  I've never done it! But, if I did it would be at Lucky Voice, one of the few karaoke bars where it seems to be more about fun than showing off.

Sgo9ICW385brUH5Jta4_Xg.text: Save your voice. You're best off whispering all day ...because if you end up visiting Lucky Voice karaoke, then you are guaranteed to be yowling deep into the night. I left what little pride and street-cred I had at the door and gazed upon the shocked faces of my friends as I foghorned my way through Whitney Houston and Chicago, via the Prodigy. Happily, they wailed along to even more embarrassing tunes in return, so at least what happened in that private room will stay there - an uneasy truce between Karaoke sinners, if you will. Oh, and the sound system rocked. Lucky Voice is the closest I've come to the KTV experiences I've had in Shanghai, except the keyboard wasn't all in Mandarin Chinese, it was a touch screen where you could search by artist or song. Although not the cheapest karaoke around, the friendly staff and ample drink choices make it a great night out for a special treat. Just don't expect to be able to answer the phone with anything more than a croaky grunt the next morning.

kIcLGu_LJlU3KTI-Uh8cQg.text: I was a little anxious about heading to my first Qype event with people whom I knew, if at all, mainly as avatars; and to my first karaoke session. To be fair, those forced to listen to me should have been more afraid but what a remarkably funny night. A couple of drinks removed most people's inhibitions and pretty soon there was competitive song queuing. It also proved to be a learning experience as I know know that You're So Vain is the only [Carly Simon] song that mentions the Canadian province of Nova Scotia For the reluctant singers, not that there will be any by the end of the night, there's a helpful book of lists: Songs for Low Voices; Hits of the 80s; Showtunes etc and the props like the blow up guitar and glitter cowboy hats all got a turn. A really silly, fun night and definitely to be recommended!

PpC3T3tQC0aqvEL2ltIkRA.text: Due to being slightly tipsy after a few cocktails on Friday, I decided to come here instead of going home. As you do. I can remember the last time I had so much fun. This isn't just your standard karaoke place, it's a really swish bar as well. Yummy cocktails too. The cocktails were around £7 so it's not overly expensive either, no more than you'd pay along the rest of Upper Street. The booths are great fun. So many karaoke places has rubbish videos along with the questionable versions of the songs, so it was nice to get something a bit more authentic. I really should know better than to go to those rubbish places in Leicester Square. Some things I've discovered: After a few drinks it's impossible not to sing along.I knock out a pretty good power ballad.I shouldn't stay out until 3am when I have work to do the next day.Karaoke gives you a hangover. Can't wait to go back! In fact, look at out for a Qype event being held here very soon

gBqp80ERni2tSvwDIrxfzA.text: Expensivebut by God it's worth it. Lucky Voice is chic and stylish and relaxed and fun. They have one of the best selections of tunes around, a brilliant bar area, but most of all they have a dressing up box in each room with comedy hats and wigs etc! Brilliant. It's a great icebreaker and means you immediately get into character for your song and 'act' it out rather than just nervously warble along. Lucky Voice also have a great website and they do an 'at home' service for parties etc too. Recommendedespecially for Karaoke virgins!

_0zFOg8zUouce_64Mdrfew.text: I really shouldn't sing. I can't sing at weddings because I end up howling too much and make myself & everyone around me laugh or want to stamp on my foot. So it's great to actually go somewhere that you can wail along to your heart's content and no one tries to shush you. The booths at Lucky Voice are just about the right size for you to feel that you're performing but at the same time aren't in some working man's club. The accessories of wigs, blow up guitars and tamborines also are a great addition. I've been to Lucky Voice twice now and I'm sure I'll go again!

AOqNC5i9QkF7hxcLb2xLLQ.text: I always did want to be popstar, and lucky voice indulges that from the safe confines of a soundproofed room. The only people who suffer are my fellow karaoke kings and queens. It is pricey to hire a room, but you quickly forget that when your mates are belting out 'More Than A Feeling' while dressed up in the fancy dress props provided. Also, Lucky Voice has a very clever way of making you feel drunker than you are. One glass of wine down and suddenly you're pelting out songs from the 'diva' section despite being painfully shy (um, not that that's a problem of mine, but there were others). Definitely recommended for a special occasion, hen do, get-together or just something different for a group of mates.

LKLxppbQ6aZBwvGbrz-MDQ.text: Okay, that was entirely too much fun. Qype held another of its famous events last night: karaoke singing (london.blog.qype.com/?p=…) at Lucky Voice (bars.luckyvoice.com/kara…) in Islington. Arranged by the fab Siany (qype.co.uk/people/Siany) , there were roughly 10 people in a room that was undoubtedly the loudest in the place. Those who know me know I don't mind belting out a tune if the time is right. Somehow I ended singing (although most songs were group singalongs anyhow) "Welcome to the Jungle" by G'n'R, "Break On Through" by The Doors, "Jump" by Van Halen, "Baby Got Back" by Sir Mix-A-Lot, "Lady is a Tramp" by Frank Sinatra, "Back In Black" by AC/DC and "Word Up" by Cameo. I'm not really looking forward to the pictures. Though, having just come from work and still in my suit, I think I raised the tone. Well, until "Baby Got Back" anyway. Super fun, though, with a good karaoke system and lots of songs to choose from. Doesn't seem to be a cheap place to drink, so watch yourself. It's a classy bar, though, with a really nice set of sofas and chairs and pavement tables out front. It's a great spot for a gang of friends to have an immense laugh.

YaZFbiwsG-TbabkQGmbeBA.text: You know, I was pretty sceptical ... I mean karaoke ...! This place changed my mind. Walking into a pretty smart bar I was greeted by Qype's Chris and Microsoft's Diane for the launch of a new Window Phone. I grabbed a lucky "budda bottle" beer and sat on some comfy leather sofas and snacked on canapes (not quite up to drinksfusion level but nice all the same) and chatted with the other qypers. We quickly moved out to three booths in the back with our personal karaoke machines (software was a bit 80's but you didn't notice after a while). Blasting out hits from Greece, Lady GaGa and Salt 'n Pepa as I fondled the tummy of my beer bottle and wore a dodgy wig was fab ... I just pity the people who had to hear my caterwauling! Come here with lots of friends - or on a work do. You won't regret it.

photos.caption: Photo of Lucky Voice Karaoke - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Lucky Voice Karaoke - London, United Kingdom

JJHw0NSl2ckvUpSeYxRaQg.text: You will indeed be lucky if you have a voice after an evening at Lucky Voice, for when you fill one of these intimate booths with your finest chorus of friends and strike up the cacophonous orchestra that features a computer screen and a song selection book that would give the OED size envy, you're in for something special. Asahi halfs for £2 + tambourines + party props - voice = a typical Sunday night as far as I'm concerned!

KSO4Opg3z1QcPH8B0ywJ_A.text: This place was great.I'm rating it six stars, because let's get frank. This place deserves it

ixzWJX5DXcDOEavYSdnS0g.text: Came to an unofficial yelp event  here where everything was fairly set up for me already so my review might be a little biased based on ease of awesomeness. The room was big and comfy and clean and disco balled.The drinks weren't cheap but tasty (well about 7 pounds for a specialty cocktail). We came here on a Sunday for one of their deals. We booked a room with a 40 pound deposit and just had to rack up an equal drinks bill to get that back. No problemo. There's an easy to reach booze button right next to the door.Going to definitely take advantage of that deal again. Good times.

omoSGZygL3Ii2BQb1eZ6Fw.text: What a find - a great karaoke venue on Upper Street in Islington with an expansive bar and seating area and, nestled in the back, 7 funky karaoke rooms where you can scream and holler to your hearts content. I had a great time here as part of a Qype event, and I will say that the staff couldn't have been more friendly and attentive, which is really saying something on Upper St, believe me! They'll even make off-menu cocktails for you if you ask nicely. As previous commenters have noted, the karaoke software really doesn't match up to the rest of Lucky Voice's image - perhaps someone should give it a bit of a makeover... :)

photos.caption: Photo of Lucky Voice Karaoke - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Lucky Voice Karaoke - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Lucky Voice Karaoke - London, United Kingdom

x9fuolZZhwqF0qDxGS04wg.text: Oh man. My throat's sore and my head hurts. Damn you, Lucky Voice! I've been to the Islington LV a couple of times now and all I can say is F-U-N! It's way better (read: more spacious) than the Soho location (which in all honestly I also love). Good song catalogue, fairly decent service (but expensive beer - oi!) and a swanky, comfortable bar/lounge area all add to the wonder that is a private karaoke experience.  Great place for a Par-tay (great excuse for one too).

hHmDQuLOMglCX1tJC_pNjw.text: So there are a few things in life that give me anxiety... One of them is Karaoke. The thought of being forced to sing in front of random strangers, while slightly intoxicated, and completely off pitch terrify me. BUT this place is fantastic! Strong drinks, check! Friendly bar tenders, check! Private rooms so you can contain your potential humiliation, CHECK! This place is nothing but a good time. Go, bring your friends, and enjoy!

zaROm4EqAq5ekHEWodvz-Q.text: "You have the voice of an angel. Your voice is like a combination of Fergie and Jesus" Whilst this could be said for myself it is sadly not true, but more so than my friend Lucy, who sounded like she was killing a pterodactyl. Following on from the escapades at The Castle on Pentonville Road (which is excellent by the way), on Easter Sunday we inevitably head for Lucky Voice in Angel. It's a fantastic night out and considering I could barely speak we still had a incredible night. For two hours of what is basically shouting at a screen, it will set you back about 15 squirrels, but what will really sting you is the drinks.  Partly because you are generally so smashed you should probably just go directly to the hospital, but also because you are having a such a good time you fail to check that a bottle of rum will set you back a small fortune. To be honest providing you can get past this, don't go there mid-month, you will be fine and you can concentrate all your efforts on blasting out 'Born to Run' at the top of your voice. The staff are also legends for putting up with us or more specifically Lucy. I do hope we didn't make them too angry... more so on the basis that we'll be rocking it again next year. I think they do food there, but let's face it you're not there for that. If you want to rock out in one for the best places in London to do Karaoke, then look no further than the Lucky Voice in Angel. Why specifically this one? Easy. They give you props to dress up with and make those post night out photos even better. I have no criticisms purely on the basis that it is such a fun night out, you'll need to take a change of pants due to all the excitement. Get. Involved.

KfZxPxv5WkhKPeCGAw_SUw.text: This place is great! I came here with a few friends and we had so much fun. Lots of music to choose from and the props make for a few good pics and laugh. Make sure you book ahead especially if you are going on Saturday!

27OljgJCRG0__gTqqWrL4A.text: I didn't do very much singing at the Qype event last night, as I was with a friend whom I had to 'bribe' just to get to the venue. We spent some time at the bar just chatting and playing with Microsoft's Ben's HTC phone, so I can testify to the incredibly wide selection of drinks and rather plush seating area at the front of the bar. Microsoft's Diane also mentioned that the new Windows 7 phone should be out before Christmas, so that's one to keep an eye out for as well. That being said, I did venture into one of the three rooms to participate in a song. I'd been to a Lucky Voice-powered karaoke bar before so am familiar with the wide range of songs available. It's really very impressive, and, in my humble opinion, could rival the karaoke bars back in Asia. You can even check out the songlist online and plan out your songlist even before getting to the bar, which is something I like to do, being such a closet mad karaoke fiend. The accessories - wigs, inflatable guitars and hats - are definitely a great touch. I can definitely say I witnessed one of the best karaoke performances ever in the form of Chris and some of the other male Qypers doing Salt & Pepa's Push It with an incredible amount of gusto. Awesome. Truly mind-blowing. And definitely a you-had-to-be-there moment... unless one of the other Qypers filmed it? ;)

jjlKqbE0bi52awYTeR1xGA.text: I do love a bit of karaoke. And it was nice having the private booths like they do in the east. This was the first sole karaoke bar I'd been to in England and I did really enjoy myself. It's just a shame that it's so expensive. Doesn't really fit into a budget.

c6DRtxas7gRsSfyxFvLkrw.text: I went here for my birthday and it was great!Their webiste publishes their up to date songlist for advance selections and their system is easy to use and you can queue up songs to keep the momentum going! You can also turn the voice/backing/echo/reverb up and down which is very handy. There's a button in your room so staff can be called on for drinks which is very fancy and they provide a box of amusing dressing up props. The only criticisms I would have is the slightly claustrophobic underground nature of their rooms and their bizarrely high levels of air-conditioning. That and some of their backing tracks and on-screen lyrics are dodgy (strange midi files for Bonnie Tyler and ridiculous rewriting of ruder Lady Gaga lyrics) but all in all the experience is great and this is a must for karaoke fans!

bVsV70uRNMZGrHf2iCZ8hA.text: What a fantastic night out! This is the poshest of karaoke clubs out there - no dingy dark rooms here. Lucky Voice has thought of everything you need for a brilliant time - lights, props, food, drinks and the most hi-tech interactive karaoke computer system I've ever seen. Went here courtesy of the new Windows phone, I should mention. What a fun evening!

kyIVg7WhHAZSswWkdj0Kjg.text: It's amazing how a mic in your hand can turn the music snob 'I'm not dancin to that!' into an 80s soft rock behemoth...Lucky Voice is a great nights craic, full of shredded vocal chords and bleeding ear drums. The mullet will have its day in the sun once again; until then, just stick on the wig.

asJgoMFYSxytjleZgbFlww.text: Low on cost, high on NRG as those lovely folks at Windows 7 Mobile hosted an interactive event where we were invited to sample their new fangled phone, while gorging on hoisin duck pancakes, snaffling mojitos and belting out glam rock classics. Possibly the best Wednesday I've had on a working week, I very quickly ditched my ahem modesty to embark on a musical escapade from David Bowie to Gaga. Donning a blonde Bon Jovi-esque wig we ran through a demanding repertoire in booth 1, the boys duetting rhythmically with the girls, harmoniously in the first 20 minutes before it all got rather rowdy and the 'uncle at a wedding' dance moves busted out their seams. Phenomenal event, met some awesome people and got a taste of the mobile revolution, yeeha!

SZVYC7Q3wG7fNtSGDAdjwg.text: I love to sing, but I'm a terrible singer and very shy, so before this particular Qype event the closest I'd come to doing Karaoke, was playing Lips (on my lonesome) on my Xbox 360. But after last night I can't wait to go back to Lucky Voice! We were welcomed by the friendly and very helpful Lucky Voice staff and served a fantastic array of canapes and drinks. Comfortably seated, watered and fed, we had My Kind of Phone's Diane give us the low down on the innovative and intuitive new Windows Mobile 7. I have to say, if this new OS is in reality, as good as it sounded last night, I'll no longer be a slave to apple! Full on canapes and tech speak, my friends and I made our way to one of Lucky Voices's Karaoke booths. To our delight, we found a box containing wigs, a hat and a tambourine and having adorned ourselves with them, began our attempt at reaching notes that would leave us voiceless by the end of the night. We had some trouble with one of the mics, but without leaving the booth and with the press of a button were able to summon a staff member who happily rectified the problem. And just like that, we were also able to order more drinks too. My friends and I had a fantastic night and we all want to go back to Lucky voice soon!

7CeLrNqZY7NTT3EOmGTLfQ.text: And to think I nearly braved going home to get some hats and tashes - private booth karaoke becomes extremely special when you have a 'thirsty' button with a useful waitress who appears in the blink of an eye and a box of dress-up paraphernalia. Now I likes me some Karaoke, it's true. In the past I was used to seedy PA systems at restaurants, caterwauling on street corners and even whispered lullabies to sleeping babes (none of mine own). Nothing prepares you for a private session though, in luxurious surroundings, with a fully stocked and prepared cocktail bar with delightful canapés and such friendly and charming hosts. My visit to the Islington branch of Lucky Voice was courtesy of Qype and Windows 7 Mobile and possibly I wouldn't have ventured so far north to check out this venue. After spending a roaring night of rapping, singing and laughing I have so many good memories that I really would consider dragging my pals to do it, not because the central London venue is booked. Even when I wandered away from the bar to munch on more Hoisin Duck pancakes (folded elegantly like a seaside chip wrapper cone) to find my Mohito delivered to a charming young lady, nothing bothered the bar staff. He was already making a replacement for me, rather then leave it to melt on the bar edge - a sign of good training and thoughtfulness. Being of Mediterranean blood, I tend to generate enough heat to power a small island and I would have preferred more air-conditioning in the booths - not to say it's rubbish - but as I danced more and got even hotter, I felt the need to take the occasional mulligan in the sumptuous bar area to cool down at times. Aside from that, top times all round!

-wFispm7uwGmWf-T8bZY1Q.text: Had a great night out here, lovely friendly people and affordable prices.Will definitely be going back!

PE9VQT1UBvj2Xdu0m39Xkg.text: Great atmosphere and really good crowd!

NyHllzbgCXTtTtMDRGjV6g.text: This is probably the classiest karoake venue in London.  If you want a bookable, pricey and Islington bound venue to ruin your vocal cords you probably can't do any better than this.  What I am a particular fan of is that the bar outside the karaoke rooms is actually quite nice which means that if (like me) you need to imbibe significant amounts of alcohol before singing there is a good place to do it.

H8q-BMkw3_uF4aW0P05Odw.text: Let's just admit that whoever says "oh I hate karaoke" is lying. Once you get in there it is infectious...Great fun can be had in the private karaoke rooms here. We had an amazing night! There's even a box with props (think wigs and inflatable guitars ;)). Drinks can be ordered from your private room and they will be brought to you - great service. They have offers on karaoke most nights of the week...We got 50% off for checking into Lucky Voice on Facebook. Awesome. Other offers include 50% off for "worthy workers", people who live in the vicinity etc.

LFTHQzRODHnxtnEfj_Nc2Q.text: Such an awesome idea, a karaoke place! I first tried the one in soho in uni days, when I never even knew it was a thing and ever since I was hooked! The black and pink theme is a total winner and In this branch they have a super cool and area with a dj and leather sofas, so it's perfect for a few drinks before you do karaoke. The cocktail menu is song themed, which is a cute idea! A particular favourite of mine is the Phil raspberry Collins which is stoli vodka with raspberries and soda.. Simple yet delicious! If you're going lucky voice the cocktails are quite pricey, so come for happy when it's 2-4-1.  If you're doing karaoke, you get your own private room and you can order cocktails and food to the room. The song list is pretty extensive and I think if you're doing karaoke you could do a lot, lot worse than check this place out!

photos.caption: Photo of Lucky Voice Karaoke - London, United Kingdom. Lucky voice top ten
Photo of Lucky Voice Karaoke - London, United Kingdom. Phil raspberry Collins

ntNXrkHvPT7kGKV7B3ahYA.text: I came here on a Friday night with a few friends without a booking and they managed to accommodate us no problem. The desk staff were very patient with us while our group decided who was up for booking the room and who didn't want to, in the end about seven of us paid separately per person for two hours (£22 each) and were shown to our room.The staff are very patient and I can only apologise to the lady who was trying to talk us through how it all worked while my friends excitedly whooped and screeched over her (not on purpose I hasten to add!)The rooms are clean and modern, with a chest full of accessories to play with like wigs, blow up guitars etc. There is a button you can press for drinks orders or help. The song choice is vast, pretty much any band or artist I could think of was on their easy to use system. We drank prosecco at £35 a bottle, which is reasonable for a place like this I think - I just wish I didn't drink so much of it! My head AND wallet hurt the next day, especially as we were having so much fun we booked another hour.The only thing I would ask of Lucky Voice would be a price list on display or easier to find on their website. It was easy to get carried away and book another hour when there was just three of us left, had I known would have been charged the same rate as it was for seven people (£77) I probably wouldn't have done so. We paid per person originally so assumed it would be the same for an extra hour but perhaps the rates go up after a certain time. Like I say, a rates card or display would be helpful on these occasions as I did feel slightly ripped off when I checked the receipt the next day. My own fault for drinking too much prosecco and not clarifying with the staff on the payment desk though.

bGA1SlvsYNZgvacncRgCTQ.text: I like this place but I didn't even do the karaoke part. I stopped in for a few drinks before dinner nearby. Yes, the drinks are a bit watered down and on the pricey side. But the plus side is that the drinks are tasty, the seats are comfortable, and they play really good music. Not a bad way to kill an hour before dinner!

PoqT8syIyjWjr_Ba9PYoGQ.text: They have every song from the grease 2 soundtrack- I mean do I need to say anymore? Many hours of fun have been had here. I love that they give a discount for worthy workers, and the staff here are all super lovely and helpful. They have some great happy hour offers, and props a plenty. There are different sized booths available which is great. Even those who are not such big fans of karaoke seem to get into it (again, happy hour!) and there is a great selection of songs incase you don't want to just sing grease 2 songs (can't imagine why you wouldn't though?) and I love the make this the last song feature which means that even if you get carried away and lose track of time you don't get cut off midway through a b side filler but instead get to go out on a high. If, like me not so long ago, you are a reluctant karaoke-er I would encourage you to give it a try here, tone deaf or otherwise for the moments that you are holding the mic you feel just like Michelle Pfeiffer in, what was the name of that film again?

nt6qFj7UctmM6OEnWb3qXQ.text: All the fun. In a padded room.Seriously, lucky voice is a great night with tuneless friends.Hire a room, compose a play list (you can even do this online prior to arrival), use their recommendations, dress up in the props and order bar service with the push of a button. Oh, and sing your heart out.Even people who think they don't like karaoke end up loving lucky voice.  Being in your own room gives you the privacy to be as silly as you want without worrying about strangers looking on.We had a fantastic two hours singing and dancing away as part of our team Xmas do. A quick intro demo, a few bottles of wine later, an extra ten minutes added by our lovely host, and we were bumbling out the door happier than when we came.The service was great, drinks London priced... Overall a great time.I'd highly recommend lucky voice in islington. It's along upper street, so plenty of bar/pub options for a tipple or two before showing Mariah Carey how it's done.

hKHf0YjQR2y_gUdi4cH0OA.text: Me and Karaoke normally do not mix. Fueled by 90 minutes of all you can drink Prosecco from a brunch at Pix, several Yelpers gathered/stumbled along Upper Street to enjoy this Sunday delight...it was the right thing to do. Key worker room discount (free): Thanks Isabelle! Clean, comfy rooms, and as other reviewers state, silly props at hand which simply get more hysterical with every song. The amusement is furthered by  happy hour 2 for 1 cocktails.Staff are polite and very efficient. Drink orders were taken and supplied quickly, and any room/sound issues resolved in a speedy fashion.Songs: Goto line 1 above. Hazel N. expertly located a Cure song, and then a Smiths song to get me to join in the fun.  After 2 Hendricks Gin and Tonics (again, after extensive Prosecco gobbling)  and crooning "Heaven Knows I'm Miserable Now " (surely a Karaoke favourite, or possibly only in Camden) , did I join in with a fantastic rendition of Tina Turner's "Private Dancer".  It was one of the best rainy Sundays I'd had in a while.  "Everyday is Like Sunday", anyone....?

cnxr68BESuY1FLYPa-9D4g.text: As a newcomer to karaoke I was impressed with Lucky Voice Karaoke on Upper Street. Having a small private room eased my nerves and allowed my tuneless drone to develop throughout the night. There was a wide selection of songs to sing plus a dress up box for those who are that way inclined. I was also impressed with the system for ordering drinks to the room.It was a shame that my first Karaoke night was Eamon B's last but I will return at some stage, many thanks to Tristan J showing me the light.

_CgzF7S6cFAH05eStZBmtw.text: The workers here are saints to put up with all the constant drunken people/shenanigans.Rooms are always clean. Fun and private. Decent selection of songs- they're certainly the go-to karaoke choice for quality and consistancy!

aNq25y9Rc8KCqBBVLKAN6w.text: * Sparkly cow boy hats - check* Inflatable guitars (for those important air guitar moments!!)* Ridiculous pink wig -check* Tambourines in the rooms - check* 50% off in the first two weeks of 2012 - check* 2 for 1 cocktails / Asahi - check (I expect this was because we arrived so early!!)* Fantastic song selection - check* Space for all 12 of my crazy friends - checkOh my goodness! This Lucky voice is fantastic!! I had such a giggle singing until my voice disappeared! We hired the huge room, drank faaar too much alcohol and it only cost £17 each. Amaze-y-balls!! @Katie - I think I might have to drag you to Karaoke with my slightly mad friends. It always seems to end up in a huge sing-along, so you never have the fear factor of warbling in front of everyone!!

5ghOYYF4eoCeIKIA7xX0vw.text: The bar was empty on a Friday night, but all the karoke booths seemed to be full. It's your typical rent a room sing-a-long fun. I think it cost £200 for 10 for 2 hours. Which isn't too bad! Staff we're quite abrupt, but would go back.

4cOcXyscDSVnOaWDDHkozg.text: A great Karaoke place, quite unexpectedly found on Upper street...Apart from the comfy singing cubicles, the rest of the place is very nice, and offers a great food a drink variety.

24fWomgBU8rdcYVssHXJoQ.text: So there was a Yelp event organised by Tristan J and Ashley, who are key workers, which means - on Sundays and Mondays, you get the room for free, as long as you spend £40 on drinks (includes the £20 deposit).  We had an amazingly fun time, the rooms were large, clean and spacey, and filled with jumbo blow-up mics, saxophones, funny hats and tambourines for laughs.  The drinks were tasty, and they were on for 2-for-1 before 8pm, so I filled up!  Otherwise, cocktails are around £9, and Asahi beer is £4.  If you're hungry, I remember seeing pizzas for £8.The songs can be searched on their touch screen, but no catalogues!  I love the planet, and I love trees - but sometimes you just need to flip through a catalogue before you find "that" song.. the "ohmygodyouguysssssssssssssss!!!" song that kicks everyone back 10-20 years to reminisce on the good old times.The screen just shows the words, and no cheesy budget videos playing in the background.  I usually find those vids annoying, but after looking at a screen full of words, I realise that cheesy vids ARE essential!While they do have a good song list, it needs improvement.  Couldn't find a few things.. 3 doors down, third eye blind, certain TLC hits to name a few.. I can think of a number of other places that have a greater selection.  So - 4 stars on the Yelp event experience (free room, and 2-for-1 drinks).  Otherwise, if I had to pay for the room - I would probably go elsewhere, mainly because of the song selection, and my preference to be able to look through a catalogue at the same time.

fKg3w9vhSxbNQkjmawSBCA.text: I had never been to a karaoke bar where they have rooms! It's very cool and private. There were about ten of us in the room. It was neat to be able to see the queue of music, and to be able to end your song if it was going on forever. No KJ was super okay! The staff here was very attentive to our drink needs. Next time I come here I'm hoping to not have a cold because that makes singing a bit easier. I would recommend coming with a larger group because I imagine it would be a little bit weird with less people. Only complaint--one of the mics didn't work as well as the other.

Ej9gweJ-4R-mc2aTbbRpKQ.text: I've been to Lucky Voice twice now, and it's been a joy on both occasions.  Have to give credit to Tristan who has been kind enough to organize the UYE Karaoke!Front of the house seems to be purely a bar area, so no singing takes place out for all the world to see.  They have several private rooms, each decked out with lovely, comfy chairs, as well as several props (inflatable instruments for air accompaniment), a tambourine, 2 mics, etc.A minor gripe in that their song selection is somewhat limited.  It breaks my angsty American heart to find only one Fiona Apple song (a standard choice for the ladies back home), and really?  No Big Country's "Big Country"?Ah well, still love the place!

4fXd5k5yuOeKoGef7g07CQ.text: I'm going to be honest - while I love karaoke in theory, the reality of holding a mic fills me with dread! It's the equivalent of the fear you feel where you dream you've forgotten you have a big exam or you've left the house naked.As I made my way to Lucky Voice I comforted myself with the knowledge that I didn't have to sing if I didn't want to and I was sure there would be people eager to fill the void.Lucky Voice comprises of a bar and a few small rooms for karaoke. You book as a group and have the room to yourself with a computerised karaoke machine to select your songs. There are plenty of songs to choose from but they also have a smaller catalogue of popular songs and it categorises them beautifully...my favourite category being 'Songs for Non-Singers'. Bingo!I felt I should brave the mic for at least one song and so opted for the backing vocals on the 'Shoop Shoop Song' (wimp!), however I soon learnt that at Lucky Voice, and in the confines of your private room, the mic isn't essential to have a jolly old time and a fantastic sing-a-long.Singers and screechers alike can have a really great time here, you'll only be amongst friends and even if the mic isn't in your hand you can guarantee you'll be singing along with the best of them anyway.I'm sold - sign me up for the next karaoke night, I feel a song coming on!

UyPFnss1bSmik-vrPMUxQw.text: Having been a fan of Lucky Voice for years, I finally visited it's Islington location a few months ago. It's almost the same cool place and we had a great night out as always. However make sure you make a reservation, otherwise it might be really difficult for you to find a place to sit.

O67qWPS3ngcO7c0dexH8Bg.text: This is a pretty decent, well-laid out Karaoke bar, with the bar out at the front and several private karaoke rooms in the back. Probably the most amazing thing about this place though is their 'book a room for two hours free of charge' deal on Monday for key workers (thanks Tristan!), which also concides with a laudable 2 for 1 deal on cocktails and draft Asahi. This meant that the cost of two hours of karaoke and two pints of Asahi came to just £4.50 - incredible value.I'm giving it four stars rather than five because the song catalogue is not as good as other places I've been to, focussing primarily on out-and-out karaoke classics. There is the odd exception to this - I was surprised to see Bloc Party's 'Flux' on the song list - but generally the more indie and alternative, the much less likely you are to find it here.Overall though, a lot of fun, and excellent value if you can find a key worker to take with you on Monday evenings.

13yn_2fxebekXzTFa95wTg.text: I have a nephew who sings with a band. He went here, as well as other K bars, to get more confidence. The reception was good and staff should congratulated on how thry look after perspective Pop Stars. Well done.

ojoVTtqR1UMg064iCmhaHA.text: There are two kinds of Karaoke bars, the ones where people sing to the entire bar, friends and strangers alike, and the ones where you seclude yourselves in a closed off room to avoid humiliation.  I prefer the former,  the entertainment value of watching drunk strangers butcher the old favorites can't be overestimated, but also because the latter often winds up being a cold white walled prison room, no liquor license with a qiant crt-tv from the early 80's your only companion.   Well, Lucky Voice breaks this mold by having state of the art touch-sensitive controls, a great flat screen, props to use, glowy padded benches reminiscent of a Virgin Atlantic flight, and alcohol service that is fast and efficient (but not cheap).  So, although I'd still rather be watching a whole room of singing drunks, being with a small group of friends playing karoake (for those without your xbox equivalent) couldn't get better than here.  The outside bar looked equally modern and attractive for drinks, as well, if the traditional pub decor of other places is getting old to you.
